Incentive Mechanism Design for Unbiased
Federated Learning with Randomized
Client Participation

Abstract

Incentive mechanism is crucial for federated learning (FL) when rational clients do not have the same interests in the global model as the server. However, due to system heterogeneity and limited budget, it is generally impractical for the server to incentivize all clients to participate in all training rounds (known as full participation). The existing FL incentive mechanisms are typically designed by stimulating a fixed subset of clients based on their data quantity or system resources. Hence, FL is performed only using this subset of clients throughout the entire training process, leading to a biased model because of data heterogeneity. This paper proposes a game-theoretic incentive mechanism for FL with randomized client participation, where the server adopts a customized pricing strategy that motivates different clients to join with different participation levels (probabilities) for obtaining an unbiased and high-performance model. Each client responds to the server’s monetary incentive by choosing its best participation level, to maximize its profit based on not only the incurred local cost but also its intrinsic value for the global model. To effectively evaluate clients’ contribution to the model performance, we derive a new convergence bound which analytically predicts how clients’ arbitrary participation levels and their heterogeneous data affect the model performance. By solving a non-convex optimization problem, our analysis reveals that the intrinsic value leads to the interesting possibility of bi-directional payment between the server and clients. Experimental results using real datasets on a hardware prototype demonstrate the superiority of our mechanism in achieving higher model performance for the server as well as higher profits for the clients.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) has recently emerged as an attractive distributed machine learning paradigm, which enables many clients to collaboratively train a machine learning model under the coordination of a central server, while keeping the training data private [1]. In FL, each client exploits its local dataset to compute a local model update, and the server periodically aggregates these local model updates to obtain a global model [2]. Because clients and the server in FL usually belong to different entities, clients may not have as much interest in obtaining a high-performance model (i.e., higher accuracy and lower loss) as the server. For instance, a company could adopt the FL framework to train a commercial model by letting its customers train the model with their local data and on their own devices, while the customers (clients) may not be interested in the model. Hence, without sufficient compensation, clients may not be willing to participate due to the associated local cost (e.g., resource consumption for computation and communication), which makes the incentive mechanism design crucial in FL systems [3, 4, 5].

However, designing an efficient and effective incentive mechanism for FL is challenging due to two unique FL features [6]: 1) clients in FL systems are usually massively distributed with different local resources and independent availability (known as system heterogeneity); 2) the training data are unbalanced and non-i.i.d. across the clients (known as statistical/data heterogeneity).

Due to system heterogeneity, it is generally impractical to design an incentive mechanism for FL that requires all clients to participate in all training rounds (known as full client participation). This is because FL usually involves a large number of clients and multiple training rounds, and incentivizing full client participation requires a considerable monetary compensation, which may be beyond the server’s budget. Moreover, clients may be only intermittently available due to their usage patterns, which prevents them from participating in every training round.

In the existing studies (e.g., [7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14]), incentive mechanism with partial client participation mainly stimulate a deterministic (fixed) subset of “valuable” clients based on their data quantity, computation or communication resources, where FL is performed only using this subset of clients throughout the entire training process. However, these mechanisms may result in a severely biased model because of statistical heterogeneity (e.g., the data at incentivized clients may not be representative of all clients’ data), which fails to converge to the optimal model that would be obtained if all the clients participate in training. Therefore, we are motivated to study the first key challenging question:

Question 1: How to design a practical incentive mechanism for FL with partial client participation, to ensure the convergence to a globally optimal unbiased model?

In tackling the bias issue due to partial client participation, recent works have proposed various client sampling and model aggregation algorithms (e.g., [15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22]), where the clients are presumed to be always active (available) upon the server’s request. This assumption may not always hold in practice, as clients are independent decision-makers with different local interests. This motivates us to explore the role of clients’ independent participation levels (probabilities) in incentive mechanism design, where the server offers monetary rewards to stimulate all clients to join with desired participation levels.

From the server’s perspective, intuitively, it can achieve a higher model performance if all clients participate at higher levels, whereas the resulting payment may be beyond the limited budget. In addition, due to statistical heterogeneity, clients with higher participation levels may have low data quality (e.g., small datasize or skewed data distribution) and thus have little contribution to the model performance. Therefore, it is critical to design an efficient payment strategy where clients who contribute more towards the global training objective receive more rewards. However, without actually training the model, it is generally impossible to determine how clients’ participation level and their non-i.i.d. data affect the model performance. This leads to our second key question:

Question 2: How to incentivize the clients’ active participation in FL by measuring the contribution of each client’s participation level and local (non i.i.d.) data on the model performance, so as to design an efficient payment strategy?

From the clients’ perspective, instead of purely providing training data and services to gain profit, clients may have intrinsic value (motivation) to participate in FL, e.g., to obtain a more powerful global model for their own use when they have few or skewed local data samples. Depending on a client’s intrinsic value, the server may adopt a flexible pricing mechanism and achieve the proper trade-off between encouraging clients’ participation and reducing the overall cost. To our best knowledge, the role of intrinsic value has not been studied in the FL incentive mechanism.

In light of the above discussion, this paper proposes a novel incentive mechanism for FL with randomized partial client participation, where the server motivates clients to join FL with different participation levels (probabilities) as shown in Fig. 1. Specifically, we model the interaction between the server and clients as a sequential two-stage Stackelberg game, where the server (leader) decides a customized pricing scheme for each client’s participation level to maximize the global model performance. Each client (follower) then responds to the server’s monetary incentive by independently choosing its best participating level to maximize its own profit, based on the incurred local cost as well as the intrinsic value for the global model.

We first develop an adaptive model aggregation scheme to guarantee the model unbiasedness for arbitrary independent client participation levels. With the unbiased design, we obtain a new FL convergence bound, which analytically establishes the relationship between the global model performance and clients’ arbitrary participation levels with unbalanced and non-i.i.d. data without actually training the model.

Then, based on the convergence bound, we obtain the Stackelberg Equilibrium (SE) via solving a non-convex optimization problem, which reveals interesting design principles. Counter-intuitively, we show that in order to achieve an unbiased global model, the server will set higher prices for clients who have larger local costs. For the clients, those with higher intrinsic values may receive lower prices (compensations) from the server and choose lower participation levels. When the clients’ intrinsic values are higher than a certain threshold, the clients may need to pay for the server for participation, which leads to a bi-directional payment.

Finally, we evaluate the result of our proposed game with both real and synthetic datasets on a hardware prototype. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of our proposed mechanism in achieving higher global model performance for the server as well as higher profits for the clients. For example, for MNIST dataset, our proposed pricing spends 69%percent6969\% less time than the baseline uniform pricing for reaching the same target accuracy under the same budget.

In summary, our key contributions are as follows:

  • •

    Unbiased Incentive Mechanism for FL with Randomized Client Participation: To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to study FL incentive mechanism with practically randomized client participation that guarantees the unbiasedness of the obtained global model towards full client participation.

  • •

    Convergence Bound for Evaluating Clients’ Contribution: We obtain a new FL convergence upper bound for clients’ arbitrary participation levels with unbalanced and non-i.i.d. data, which allows us to effectively measure each client’s contribution to the global model performance.

  • •

    Intrinsic Value Design: We prove that the intrinsic value can lead to a flexible bi-directional payment between the server and clients. As far as we know, this is the first work that models the impact of clients’ intrinsic value in the FL incentive mechanism.

  • •

    Insightful Equilibrium Properties:

    We obtain insightful design principles that characterize the impact of the server’s and clients’ system parameters. In particular, our analysis reveals a counter-intuitive result that the sever may set higher prices for clients who have larger local costs in order to guarantee the model unbiasedness.

  • •

    Experimental Evaluation with Hardware Prototype: We provide hardware experimental results that demonstrate the superiority of our proposed mechanism with a 69%percent6969\% time savings compared to baseline uniform pricing for MNIST dataset under the same budget.

II Related Works

Incentive mechanism design for FL has received significant attention over recent years (for a comprehensive review please refer to [23]). In the literature, existing works mainly focus on designing incentives mechanism with full client participation (e.g., [24, 25, 26, 27]).

Considering the server’s limited budget and clients’ heterogeneous local resources, recent FL incentive mechanisms (e.g., [7, 8, 9]) have considered more practical partial client participation scenarios. However, these works mainly stimulate a deterministic subset of “valuable” clients and train the global model only with these clients’ data. Although such mechanisms may speed up the training process at a certain level and have merits in eliciting clients’ private information, they may result in a biased global model if the selected clients have skewed data. We propose to incentivize all clients to join FL with independent participation probabilities, which enables the server to obtain all clients’ data contributions to guarantee the model’s unbiasedness.

In addition, most existing incentive mechanisms evaluate clients’ contribution based on their data quantity (e.g., [7, 8, 13, 9, 12]) or computation/communication resources (e.g., [12, 24, 25, 27, 9, 10, 11, 14]), which do not capture the critical heterogeneous data distribution across clients. Our mechanism measures clients’ contribution via a theoretical convergence result for general statistical heterogeneity with unbalanced and non-i.i.d. data.

The organization of the rest of the paper is as follows. Section III introduces federated learning and game model. Section IV presents our new error-convergence bound with randomized client participation level. Section V analyzes the equilibrium of the proposed game and solution insights. Section VI provides hardware-based cross-device experimental results. We conclude this paper in Section VII.

III Federated Learning and Game Model

We first introduce the basics of FL with partial client participation and the proposed unbiased and independent client participation scheme in Section III-A. Then, we present the incentive mechanism design for client participation level (probability), and describe the decision problems for the server and clients, respectively in Section III-B. Finally, Section III-C presents the strategic interactions between the server and clients with the proposed Stackelberg game as well as the challenges in solving the game.

III-A FL with Randomized Partial Client Participation

We consider a typical FL scenario, where a central server wants to learn a model based on the data from a set 𝒩={1,…,N}𝒩1…𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,\ldots,N\} clients. Each client n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N} has dnsubscript𝑑𝑛d_{n} data samples, (𝒙n,1,…,𝒙n,dnsubscript𝒙𝑛1…subscript𝒙𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛\boldsymbol{x}_{n,1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{x}_{n,d_{n}}), which is distributed in a non-i.i.d. fashion. Define f​(𝒘;𝒙n,i)𝑓𝒘subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖{{f}\left(\boldsymbol{w};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i}\right)} as the loss function, indicating how the machine learning model parameter 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w} performs on the data sample 𝒙n,isubscript𝒙𝑛𝑖\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i}. Thus, the local loss function of client n𝑛n is

Fn​(𝒘):=1dn​∑i=1dnf​(𝒘;𝒙n,i).assignsubscript𝐹𝑛𝒘1subscript𝑑𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑑𝑛𝑓𝒘subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖{F_{n}}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right):=\frac{1}{{{d_{n}}}}\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{d_{n}}{{f}\left(\boldsymbol{w};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i}\right)}. (1)

We further denote an=dn/∑n=1Ndnsubscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑑𝑛a_{n}={d_{n}}/{\sum\nolimits_{n=1}^{N}\!d_{n}} as the weight of the n𝑛n-th device, where ∑n=1Nan=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑎𝑛1\sum\nolimits_{n=1}^{N}a_{n}=1. By denoting F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right) as the global loss function, the goal of FL is to solve the following optimization problem [1]:

min𝒘⁡F​(𝒘):=∑n=1Nan​Fn​(𝒘).assignsubscript𝒘𝐹𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝐹𝑛𝒘\min_{\boldsymbol{w}}F\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right):=\sum\nolimits_{n=1}^{N}{a_{n}}{F_{n}}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right). (2)

Due to limited system bandwidth and clients’ diverse availability, the most popular and de facto optimization algorithm to solve (2) is FedAvg [2]. In FedAvg, the server randomly samples a fraction of K𝐾K clients (known as partial client participation) in each round, and each selected client performs multiple (e.g., E𝐸E) steps of local stochastic gradient descent (SGD) iterations on (1). Then, the server aggregates their resulting local model updates periodically for a given deadline of R𝑅R rounds or until the global loss (2) converges.

However, considering that clients in FL are independent decision-makers, each client n𝑛n can decide its own participation level (probability) qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n}, instead of using the sampling probability decided by the server. Nevertheless, without a careful algorithm design, the obtained global model can be severely biased due to statistical heterogeneity.

In the following, before we present our incentive mechanism design, we first propose an unbiased model aggregation scheme under an arbitrary independent client participation level 𝒒={q1,…,qN}𝒒subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞𝑁\boldsymbol{q}\!=\!\{q_{1},\ldots,q_{N}\}, such that the obtained model based on our mechanism is unbiased towards full client participation. We define the weighted aggregated model with full client participation for any round r𝑟r as 𝒘¯r+1:=∑n=1Nan​𝒘nr+1assignsuperscript¯𝒘𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑎𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑟1\overline{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r+1}:=\sum\nolimits_{n=1}^{N}a_{n}\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{r+1}. With this, we have the following result.

Lemma 1.

(Unbiased FL with Independent Client Participation Level) For clients under an arbitrary participation level 𝐪𝐪\boldsymbol{q}, we aggregate the participants’ local updates as

𝒘r+1←𝒘r+∑n∈𝒮​(𝒒)ranqn​(𝒘nr+1−𝒘r),←superscript𝒘𝑟1superscript𝒘𝑟subscript𝑛𝒮superscript𝒒𝑟subscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑟1superscript𝒘𝑟\boldsymbol{w}^{r+1}\leftarrow\boldsymbol{w}^{r}+\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}(\boldsymbol{q})^{r}}\frac{a_{n}}{q_{n}}\left(\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{r+1}-\boldsymbol{w}^{r}\right), (3)

where 𝒮​(𝐪)r𝒮superscript𝐪𝑟\mathcal{S}(\boldsymbol{q})^{r} is the participating client set in round r𝑟r. Then, we have

𝔼𝒮​(𝒒)r​[𝒘r+1]=𝒘¯r+1.subscript𝔼𝒮superscript𝒒𝑟delimited-[]superscript𝒘𝑟1superscript¯𝒘𝑟1\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{S}(\boldsymbol{q})^{r}}[\boldsymbol{w}^{r+1}]=\overline{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r+1}. (4)
Proof.

We give the proof in Appendix A. ∎

Remark: The interpretation of our aggregation scheme is similar to that of importance sampling. More specifically, we inversely re-weight the participant’s updated model gradient in the aggregation step (e.g., 1qn1subscript𝑞𝑛\frac{1}{q_{n}} for client n𝑛n), such that the aggregated model is unbiased towards the true update with full client participation. We note that simply inversely weighting the model updates from the sampled clients does not yield an unbiased global model, i.e. 𝔼𝒦​(𝒒)(r)​[∑i∈𝒦​(𝒒)(r)piK​qi​𝐰i(r+1)]≠𝐰¯(r+1)subscript𝔼𝒦superscript𝒒𝑟delimited-[]subscript𝑖𝒦superscript𝒒𝑟subscript𝑝𝑖𝐾subscript𝑞𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑟1superscript¯𝐰𝑟1\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{K}(\boldsymbol{q})^{(r)}}[\sum_{i\in\mathcal{K}(\boldsymbol{q})^{(r)}}\frac{p_{i}}{Kq_{i}}\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(r+1)}]\neq\overline{\mathbf{w}}^{(r+1)}, as the equality holds only when clients are sampled uniformly at random, i.e., qi=1/Nsubscript𝑞𝑖1𝑁{q_{i}}=1/N. Particularly, when qn=1subscript𝑞𝑛1q_{n}=1 for all n𝑛n, 𝒮​(𝒒)r𝒮superscript𝒒𝑟\mathcal{S}(\boldsymbol{q})^{r} is the full set with all N𝑁N clients, and 𝒘r+1superscript𝒘𝑟1\boldsymbol{w}^{r+1} in (3) recovers 𝒘¯r+1superscript¯𝒘𝑟1\overline{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r+1}. Nevertheless, unlike most active sampling schemes (e.g., [15, 16, 17, 22]) where clients’ sampling probabilities qnsamsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛samq_{n}^{\text{sam}} are dependent with ∑n=1Nqnsam=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛sam1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{n}^{\text{sam}}=1, the clients’ participation levels qnsubscript𝑞𝑛{q_{n}} in our model is independent from each other with the sum ∑n=1Nqnsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑛\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{n} varying between 00 to N𝑁N.

III-B Mechanism Design for Randomized Client Participation

As clients are independent decision-makers, we will explore the impact of clients’ independent participation levels (probabilities) 𝒒={q1,…,qN}𝒒subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞𝑁\boldsymbol{q}=\{q_{1},\ldots,q_{N}\} in the incentive mechanism design. Specifically, under a limited payment budget, the server designs a customized pricing scheme for each client’s participation level to maximize the model performance. In the following, we present the decision problems for the server and the clients.

III-B1 Server’s Decision Problem

The goal of the server is to minimize the training loss defined in (2) for a certain number of training rounds. To achieve this, the server imposes a set of prices 𝑷={P1,…,PN}𝑷subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑁\boldsymbol{P}=\{P_{1},\ldots,P_{N}\} to incentivize each client’s independent participation level (probability) 𝒒={q1,…,qN}𝒒subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞𝑁\boldsymbol{q}=\{q_{1},\ldots,q_{N}\} under a payment budget B𝐵B, where Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} represents the price per unit of client i𝑖i’s participating level. Hence, the payment for each client n𝑛n is Pn​qnsubscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛P_{n}q_{n}.

Let us denote 𝒘R​(𝒒)superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q}) as the obtained model after R𝑅R rounds when clients participate with level 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} under pricing strategy 𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P}. We can formulate the server’s problem as the following P1:

P1:min𝑷P1:subscript𝑷\displaystyle\textbf{P1:}\ \ \min_{\boldsymbol{P}}\ Us​(𝑷,𝒒):=𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))],assignsubscript𝑈𝑠𝑷𝒒𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒\displaystyle U_{s}(\boldsymbol{P,q}):=\mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)\right], (5a)
s.t. ∑n=1NPn​qn≤B.superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛𝐵\displaystyle\ \ \sum\nolimits_{n=1}^{N}P_{n}q_{n}\leq B. (5b)

The expectation of the objective in (5a) comes from the randomness in client’s participation level 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} and local SGD. Since the total budget is limited, it is important for the server to design the optimal pricing strategy 𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P} to maximize its utility.

Remark: Unlike existing incentive mechanisms in FL where the server always pays for the clients (e.g., Pn≥0subscript𝑃𝑛0P_{n}\geq 0, for all n𝑛n) [7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14], we allow the payment to be bi-directional. This is because, instead of purely providing training data and computing services, if some client n𝑛n has a high appreciation for the global model as we will show later, it may be willing to pay for the server (i.e., Pn<0subscript𝑃𝑛0P_{n}<0).

III-B2 Clients’ Decision Problem

Each client’s goal is to choose its participation level qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n} to maximize its utility function Unsubscript𝑈𝑛U_{n}, based on its incurred local cost and its intrinsic value for the global model, which we will explain next.

Local Cost Model. The cost of client n𝑛n involves resource consumption for model computation and communication as well as the lost opportunity for joining other activities for monetary reward. Intuitively, the higher participation level the higher cost will be, so we model the cost function Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n} as

Cn=cn​qnτ,τ>1, 0≤qn≤qn,max.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝑐𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛𝜏formulae-sequence𝜏1 0subscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛maxC_{n}=c_{n}q_{n}^{\tau},\ \tau>1,\ 0\leq q_{n}\leq q_{n,\text{max}}. (6)

The exponent τ>1𝜏1\tau>1 captures a broad class of convex cost functions, indicating an increasing rate as qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n} increases. We let τ=2𝜏2\tau=2 for analytical tractability in the rest of the paper, which is also a standard assumption in economic models when the decision variable is constrained [28], e.g., qn≤qn,maxsubscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛maxq_{n}\leq q_{n,\text{max}}. Nevertheless, we claim that our theoretical results in this paper also hold for an arbitrary τ>1𝜏1\tau>1. Parameter cn>0subscript𝑐𝑛0c_{n}>0 is the local cost parameter.

Intrinsic Value Model. In addition to incurring the resource cost, clients may have intrinsic motivation to participate in FL, e.g., obtaining the powerful global model. In order to effectively model the intrinsic value, we denote F​(𝒘n∗)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛F({\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{*}}) as the loss when client n𝑛n applies its locally optimal model 𝒘n∗superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{*} into the global loss function (2), where 𝒘n∗=arg⁡min𝒘⁡Fn​(𝒘)superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛subscript𝒘subscript𝐹𝑛𝒘\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{*}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{w}}{F_{n}(\boldsymbol{w})} is solved using client’s local training data on its local loss function Fn​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑛𝒘{F_{n}(\boldsymbol{w})} as defined in (1). Then, we model the intrinsic value Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} for client n𝑛n as

Vn:=vn​(F​(𝒘n∗)−𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]).assignsubscript𝑉𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛𝐹superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒V_{n}:=v_{n}\left(F({\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{*}})-\mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)\right]\right). (7)

The value of F​(wn∗)−𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑛𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒F({w_{n}^{*}})-\mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)\right] represents the improvement of model performance due to the participation in FL. Parameter vn≥0subscript𝑣𝑛0v_{n}\geq 0 is the preference level for the improvement, since clients may have different preferences for the same model improvement. Intuitively, given that F​(𝒘n∗)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛F({\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{*}}) is a constant value and independent of 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q}, a lower 𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)\right] yields a higher intrinsic value Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n}, indicating that client n𝑛n has an internal drive to minimize the server’s utility in (5a).

Based on the above, we formulate each client n𝑛n’s decision problem as follows:

s.t.0s.t.0\displaystyle\text{s.t.}\ \quad 0 ≤qn≤qn,max.absentsubscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛max\displaystyle\leq q_{n}\leq q_{n,\text{max}}. (8b)

Remark: As we discussed in the previous subsection, due to the existence of the intrinsic value, clients may have incentives to participate in FL even without monetary reward, i.e., Pn=0subscript𝑃𝑛0P_{n}=0. In certain cases, when some client n𝑛n has a very high intrinsic value vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n}, it is possible for client n𝑛n to pay for the server for participation, i.e., Pn<0subscript𝑃𝑛0P_{n}<0.

III-C Stackelberg Game Formulation

As shown in Fig. 2, we model the sequential decision-making between the server and clients as a two-stage Stackelberg game [29], where the server acts as the Stackelberg leader and decides the pricing variables 𝑷={P1,…,PN}𝑷subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑁\boldsymbol{P}=\{P_{1},\ldots,P_{N}\} to minimize its utility defined in (5a) in Stage I. Then, given the server’s pricing strategy 𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P}, each client acts as a Stackelberg follower and chooses its reactive participation level qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n} to maximize its utility defined in (8a) in Stage II. In the following, we refer to the proposed Stackelberg game as Client Participation Level Game (CPL Game).111Our mechanism assumes complete information, focusing on evaluating clients’ contribution and designing an effective payment scheme. For the more realistic incomplete information scenario, we can adopt Bayesian method to model and analyze the performance similarly with a higher complexity.

III-C1 Solution Concept of the Proposed CPL Game

The common solution concept of the CPL Game is Stackelberg equilibrium (SE), which we define as follows.

Definition 1.

The Stackelberg equilibrium (SE) of the CPL Game is a set of decisions {𝐏SE,𝐪SE}superscript𝐏SEsuperscript𝐪SE\{\boldsymbol{P}^{{\text{SE}}},\boldsymbol{q}^{\text{SE}}\} satisfying

qnSE​(𝑷)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛SE𝑷\displaystyle q_{n}^{\text{SE}}(\boldsymbol{P}) =arg⁡maxqn​(𝑷)⁡Un​(qn​(𝑷)),∀n∈𝒩,formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛𝑷subscript𝑈𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛𝑷for-all𝑛𝒩\displaystyle=\arg\max_{q_{n}(\boldsymbol{P})}{U_{n}}\left(q_{n}(\boldsymbol{P})\right),\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, (9a)
𝑷SEsuperscript𝑷SE\displaystyle\boldsymbol{P}^{\text{SE}} =arg⁡min𝑷⁡Us​(𝑷,𝒒SE​(𝑷)).absentsubscript𝑷subscript𝑈𝑠𝑷superscript𝒒SE𝑷\displaystyle=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{P}}U_{s}\left(\boldsymbol{P},\boldsymbol{q}^{\text{SE}}(\boldsymbol{P})\right). (9b)

At a SE, neither the server or the clients has incentive to deviate for better choice. A powerful technique to obtain SE is backward induction [30], where we first solve for clients’ decision-making 𝒒​(𝑷)𝒒𝑷\boldsymbol{q(P)} given the server’s pricing scheme 𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P} in Stage II, and then move back to Stage I to determine the server’s pricing strategy 𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P}.

III-C2 Challenges in Solving the CPL Game

Solving the CPL Game, however, is challenging due to the lack of an analytical expression of 𝔼​[F​(𝐰R​(𝐪))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑅𝐪\mathbb{E}[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)] to characterize the impact of 𝐪𝐪\boldsymbol{q}. Hence, it is difficult for the server to evaluate the clients’ contributions and make an efficient pricing decision. Moreover, in general, without actually training the model, it is impossible to find out how 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} affects the final model 𝒘R​(𝒒)superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q}) and the corresponding loss 𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)].

We will show how to address the above challenge in Section IV, and then we will find the SE solution for the CPL Game in Section V.

IV Convergence Analysis for Randomized Client Participation Level

In this section, we address the challenge mentioned in Section III-C2 by deriving a new tractable error-convergence bound. The convergence bound establishes the analytical relationship between 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} and 𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)], which allows us to approximate 𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)] in Ussubscript𝑈𝑠U_{s} and Unsubscript𝑈𝑛U_{n} and analytically solve the PCL Game.

IV-A Key Assumptions

Assumption 1.

For each client n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N}, Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} is L𝐿L-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex.

Assumption 2.

For each client n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N}, the stochastic gradient of Fnsubscript𝐹𝑛F_{n} is unbiased with its variance bounded by σn2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\sigma_{n}^{2}.

Assumption 3.

For each client n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N}, the expected squared norm of its stochastic gradient is bounded by Gn2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛2G_{n}^{2}.

Assumptions 1 and 2 are commonly made in many existing studies of convex FL problems, such as ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm regularized linear regression, logistic regression (e.g., [16, 31, 18, 32, 17, 21]). Nevertheless, in Assumption 3, we make an assumption for each client n with the bound Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n} instead of the bound G𝐺G for all the clients as in [16, 31, 18, 32, 17, 21]. This is because if clients’ data are i.i,d., then Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n} would be the same across the clients since each client locally performs SGD from the same data distribution. However, when clients have non-i.i.d. data distribution, the values of Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n} would be different, which not only characterizes the data heterogeneity in our convergence result but also yields a more accurate pricing design (as we will show in Section V). In practice, we can estimate Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n} by letting the participated clients send back their actual local stochastic gradient norms computed along the trajectory of the model updates.

IV-B Bounded Model Variance

We first present the introduced variance of the aggregated model 𝒘r+1superscript𝒘𝑟1\boldsymbol{w}^{r+1} in (3) due to randomized client participation.

Lemma 2.

The variance between the aggregated model 𝐰r+1superscript𝐰𝑟1\boldsymbol{w}^{r+1} in (3) and the global model with full participation 𝐰¯r+1superscript¯𝐰𝑟1\overline{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r+1} is bounded as

𝔼𝒮​(𝒒)r​‖𝒘r+1−𝒘¯r+1‖2≤4​∑n=1N(1−qn)​an2​Gn2qn​(ηr​E)2.subscript𝔼𝒮superscript𝒒𝑟superscriptnormsuperscript𝒘𝑟1superscript¯𝒘𝑟124superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁1subscript𝑞𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛2subscript𝑞𝑛superscriptsuperscript𝜂𝑟𝐸2\begin{array}[]{l}\!\!\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{S}(\boldsymbol{q})^{r}}\!\left\|\boldsymbol{w}^{r\!+\!1}\!-\!\overline{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r\!+\!1}\right\|^{2}\leq 4\!\sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}\!\dfrac{\left(1\!-\!q_{n}\right)a_{n}^{2}G_{n}^{2}}{q_{n}}\left({\eta^{r}}E\right)^{2}.\!\!\!\end{array} (10)

Proof Sketch. The proof follows a similar argument of Lemma 5 in [16], except that our client participation levels qnsubscript𝑞𝑛{q_{n}} are independent among each other, which does not satisfy the assumption of ∑n=1Nqn=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑛1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{n}\!=\!1 made in [16].         ∎

Remark: When qn=1subscript𝑞𝑛1q_{n}=1 for all n𝑛n, the variance in (10) is equal to zero, since the aggregated model 𝒘r+1superscript𝒘𝑟1\boldsymbol{w}^{r+1} in the left hand side of (10) is the same as 𝒘¯r+1superscript¯𝒘𝑟1\overline{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r+1} because qn=1subscript𝑞𝑛1q_{n}=1 implies full participation.

IV-C Main Convergence Result

Theorem 1.

(Convergence Upper Bound under an Arbitrary 𝐪𝐪\boldsymbol{q}) Consider any given client participation level 𝐪={q1,…,qN}𝐪subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞𝑁\boldsymbol{q}=\{q_{1},\ldots,q_{N}\} and the unbiased aggregation in Lemma 1, if we choose the decaying learning rate ηr=2max⁡{8​L,μ​E}+μ​rsubscript𝜂𝑟28𝐿𝜇𝐸𝜇𝑟\eta_{r}=\frac{2}{\max\{{8L},\mu E\}+\mu r}, the optimality gap after R𝑅R rounds satisfies

𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]−F∗≤1R​(α​∑n=1N(1−qn)​an2​Gn2qn+β),𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒superscript𝐹1𝑅𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁1subscript𝑞𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛2subscript𝑞𝑛𝛽\begin{array}[]{c}\mathbb{E}[F\!\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)]\!-\!F^{*}\!\leq\dfrac{1}{R}\!\left(\alpha{\sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}\dfrac{\left(1\!-\!q_{n}\right)a_{n}^{2}G_{n}^{2}}{q_{n}}}\!+\!\beta\right)\!,\!\!\end{array} (11)

where α=8​L​Eμ2𝛼8𝐿𝐸superscript𝜇2\alpha=\frac{8LE}{\mu^{2}}, β=2​Lμ2​E​A0+12​L2μ2​E​Γ+4​L2μ​E​‖𝐰0−𝐰∗‖2𝛽2𝐿superscript𝜇2𝐸subscript𝐴012superscript𝐿2superscript𝜇2𝐸Γ4superscript𝐿2𝜇𝐸superscriptnormsubscript𝐰0superscript𝐰2\beta=\frac{2L}{\mu^{2}E}A_{0}+\frac{12L^{2}}{\mu^{2}E}\Gamma+\frac{4L^{2}}{\mu E}\left\|\boldsymbol{w}_{0}-\boldsymbol{w}^{*}\right\|^{2}, A0=∑n=1Nan2​σn2+8​∑n=1Nan​Gn2​(E−1)2subscript𝐴0superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛28superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑎𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛2superscript𝐸12A_{0}\!=\!\sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}\!a_{n}^{2}\sigma_{n}^{2}\!+\!8\sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}a_{n}G_{n}^{2}(E\!-\!1)^{2}, and Γ=F∗−∑n=1Nan​Fn∗Γsuperscript𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑎𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑛\Gamma\!=\!F^{*}\!-\!\sum_{n=1}^{N}a_{n}F_{n}^{*}.

Proof.

We give the proof in Appendix B. ∎

We summarize the key insights of Theorem 1 as follows:

  • •

    The bound in (11) is valid for arbitrary independent client participating level 𝐪𝐪\boldsymbol{q} and variant number of participating clients in each round (i.e., ∑n=1Nqnsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑞𝑛\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{n} can vary between 00 to N𝑁N), which is the key difference from existing convergence results with active client sampling [22, 15, 16, 17, 19, 18, 21].

  • •

    The bound in (11) characterizes how randomized partial client participation (i.e., qn<1subscript𝑞𝑛1q_{n}<1) worsens the convergence rate compared to full client participation. It also indicates that in order to obtain an unbiased global model, all clients need to participate with non-zero probability for model convergence, i.e., qn>0subscript𝑞𝑛0q_{n}>0, for all n𝑛n. This is because when qn→0→subscript𝑞𝑛0q_{n}\rightarrow 0, it will take infinite number of rounds R𝑅R for convergence. Our bound also explains why only incentivizing and training part of the clients in existing mechanisms (e.g., [7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14]) may fail to converge to the optimal global model.

  • •

    The convergence bound in (11) establishes the relationship between the expected loss function 𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)], clients’ participation level 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q}, and their heterogeneous data an​Gnsubscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝐺𝑛a_{n}G_{n}. In other words, how clients’ unbalanced data (ansubscript𝑎𝑛a_{n}) and non-i.i.d. data distribution (Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n}) affect the model training. This not only provides analytical utility expressions for the server Ussubscript𝑈𝑠U_{s} and clients Unsubscript𝑈𝑛U_{n}, but also enables an efficient pricing strategy as we will show in Section V.

The use of Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} in our convergence analysis (instead of more accurate instantaneous gradient norms) is mainly due to the challenging “chicken and egg” problem. Specifically, before the model has been fully trained, it is generally impossible to know exactly how different FL configurations (e.g., clients’ different participation levels in this paper) affect the FL performance. Therefore, to optimize the FL performance, we need to have a lightweight surrogate that can (approximately) predict what will happen if we choose a specific configuration. A common surrogate used for this purpose is the convergence upper bound, which has become a common practice in the communications and networking community (e.g., [33, 22, 34, 35, 36, 37]). Moreover, our experiments in Section VI demonstrate the superiority of our designed pricing scheme based on the convergence bound, in terms of achieving higher global model performance and higher client profits compared to baseline schemes.

V Stackelberg Equilibrium Analysis

In this section, we use the obtained convergence bound in Theorem 1 to approximate 𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)] in the server’s utility Ussubscript𝑈𝑠U_{s} and clients’ utility Unsubscript𝑈𝑛U_{n}, and solve the CPL Game via backward induction. We first solve clients’ decision-making 𝒒𝒒\boldsymbol{q} given the server’s pricing scheme 𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P} in Stage II, and then move back to Stage I to determine 𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P}. Finally, we characterize the key insights of the optimal solution.

V-A Client’s Decision at Stage II

We approximate 𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒\mathbb{E}[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)] with the convergence bound in (11), and rewrite client n𝑛n’s problem given the server’s pricing strategy 𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P} as the following Problem P2′:

We observe that the objective function (12a) is concave in qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n}. Along with the linear constraints in (12b), we conclude that Problem P2′ is concave. Therefore, the optimal solution of Problem P2′ is unique, which is the best choice of qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n} to maximize its own utility.

Based on the first order condition, the optimal choice of qn∗​(Pn)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛q_{n}^{*}(P_{n}) for client n𝑛n satisfies

Pn+vn​αR​an2​Gn2qn∗2−2​cn​qn∗=0.subscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛𝛼𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛absent22subscript𝑐𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛0\displaystyle P_{n}+v_{n}\frac{\alpha}{R}\frac{a_{n}^{2}G_{n}^{2}}{q_{n}^{*2}}-2c_{n}q_{n}^{*}=0. (13)

Although the closed form solution of qn∗​(Pn)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛q_{n}^{*}(P_{n}) is complicated because (13) is a cubic equation, we can show that qn∗​(Pn)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛q_{n}^{*}(P_{n}) is a monotonically increasing convex function in Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n}.

Based on the client’s optimal solution in (13), we move to Stage I of the CPL game.

V-B Server’s Decision at Stage I

In Stage I, the server chooses its pricing strategy based on all the clients’ best responses. In other words, the server substitutes qn∗​(Pn)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛q_{n}^{*}(P_{n}) into its utility function in (5) for obtaining the optimal price vector 𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P} under the budget constraint B𝐵B.

However, since the analytical expression of qn​(Pn)subscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛q_{n}(P_{n}) is complicated, it is difficult to obtain the optimal 𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P} in the server’s decision problem. As qn∗​(Pn)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛∗subscript𝑃𝑛q_{n}^{\ast}(P_{n}) is unique, we can write its inverse function based on (13), i.e., Pn​(qn)=2​cn​qn−an2​Gn2/qn2subscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛2subscript𝑐𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛2P_{n}(q_{n})=2c_{n}q_{n}-{a_{n}^{2}G_{n}^{2}}/{q_{n}^{2}}. Then, we substitute this expression of Pn​(qn)subscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛P_{n}(q_{n}) into the server’s utility function and solve Stage I problem in (5). Therefore, with the obtained convergence bound and the constraints of qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n}, we rewrite problem in (5) as the following Problem P1′:

For any fixed feasible value of M𝑀M, Problem P1′′ is convex because the objective function and the constraints are convex. Hence, we can approximately solve Problem P1′′ in two steps. First, for any fixed M𝑀M, we solve for the optimal 𝒒∗​(M)superscript𝒒𝑀\boldsymbol{q}^{*}(M) in Problem P1′′ via a convex optimization tool, e.g., CVX [38]. This allows us to write the objective function of Problem P1′′ as g​(𝒒∗​(M),M)𝑔superscript𝒒∗𝑀𝑀g(\boldsymbol{q}^{\ast}(M),M). Then we will further solve the problem by using a linear search method with a fixed step-size ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0} over the interval [0,∑n=1Ncn​qn,max2]0superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑐𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛max2\left[0,\sum_{n=1}^{N}c_{n}{q_{n,\text{max}}^{2}}\right], which leads to 𝒒∗​(M∗​(ϵ0))=arg⁡minM​(ϵ0)⁡𝒒∗​(M​(ϵ0))superscript𝒒superscript𝑀subscriptitalic-ϵ0subscript𝑀subscriptitalic-ϵ0superscript𝒒𝑀subscriptitalic-ϵ0\boldsymbol{q}^{*}(M^{*}(\epsilon_{0}))=\arg\min_{M(\epsilon_{0})}\boldsymbol{q}^{*}(M(\epsilon_{0})).

Once we obtain 𝒒∗superscript𝒒\boldsymbol{q}^{*} from Problem P1′′, we immediately have the optimal price 𝑷∗superscript𝑷\boldsymbol{P}^{*} via (13) as follows,

Pn∗=2​cn​qn∗−vn​αR​an2​Gn2qn∗2.superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛2subscript𝑐𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛𝛼𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛2P_{n}^{*}=2c_{n}q_{n}^{*}-v_{n}\frac{\alpha}{R}\frac{a_{n}^{2}G_{n}^{2}}{{q_{n}^{*}}^{2}}. (17)

Finally, we conclude that the obtained solution pair {𝒒∗,𝑷∗}superscript𝒒superscript𝑷\{\boldsymbol{q}^{*},\boldsymbol{P}^{*}\} based on backward induction are the SE {𝑷SE,𝒒SE}superscript𝑷SEsuperscript𝒒SE\{\boldsymbol{P}^{{\text{SE}}},\boldsymbol{q}^{{\text{SE}}}\} for the proposed CPL game [29]. Notably, based on the relationship between qnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛SEq_{n}^{{\text{SE}}} and PnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛SEP_{n}^{{\text{SE}}} in (17), we highlight that clients with low participation level qnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛SEq_{n}^{{\text{SE}}} will receive a low price PnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛SEP_{n}^{{\text{SE}}}, which leads to a low payment PnSE​qnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛SEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛SEP_{n}^{{\text{SE}}}q_{n}^{{\text{SE}}} from the server. In particular, if these clients with low participation levels also have high intrinsic value vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n}, they may need to pay for the server, i.e., PnSE<0superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛SE0P_{n}^{\text{SE}}<0, which we show in the next section.

V-C Properties of SE in the CPL Game

This subsection presents some interesting properties of the obtained SE {𝑷SE,𝒒SE}superscript𝑷SEsuperscript𝒒SE\{\boldsymbol{P}^{\text{SE}},\boldsymbol{q}^{\text{SE}}\}. Before that, we first give the following lemma which leads to our property analysis.

Lemma 3.

At the SE of the CPL Game, the server’s budget constraint is tight.

Proof Sketch. The idea of this proof is to use contradiction, which we omit due to page limitation.         ∎

V-C1 Impact of the server’s budget B𝐵B

We first show the impact of the server’s budget B𝐵B on SE {𝑷SE,𝒒SE}superscript𝑷SEsuperscript𝒒SE\{\boldsymbol{P}^{\text{SE}},\boldsymbol{q}^{\text{SE}}\}.

Proposition 1.

Both 𝐏SEsuperscript𝐏SE\boldsymbol{P}^{\text{SE}} and 𝐪SEsuperscript𝐪SE\boldsymbol{q}^{\text{SE}} increase in budget B𝐵B.

Proof.

Given B=∑n=1N(2​cn​qn∗2−αR​vn​an2​Gn2qn∗)𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁2subscript𝑐𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛2𝛼𝑅subscript𝑣𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛B\!=\!\sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}\left(2c_{n}{q_{n}^{*}}^{2}-\!\frac{\alpha}{R}\frac{v_{n}a_{n}^{2}G_{n}^{2}}{q_{n}^{*}}\right) from Lemma 3, we have ∂B/∂qn∗=4​cn​qn∗+αR​vn​an2​Gn2qn∗2>0𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛4subscript𝑐𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛𝛼𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛20{\partial B}/{\partial q_{n}^{*}}=4c_{n}q_{n}^{*}+\frac{\alpha}{R}\frac{v_{n}a_{n}^{2}G_{n}^{2}}{q_{n}^{*}}^{2}>0. Thus, qn∗superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n}^{*} increases in B𝐵B. Next, based on the monotonically increasing relationship between qn∗superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n}^{*} and Pn∗superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n}^{*} in (17), we conclude that Pn∗superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n}^{*} also increases in B𝐵B. ∎

Proposition 1 shows that when the budget B𝐵B is higher, the server could increase its price Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n} to incentivize higher client participation level qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n} to decrease the global loss for improving the model performance. Similarly, clients also have incentive to increase their participation level for more profit.

V-C2 Impact of clients’ parameters

This subsection shows how client’s parameters, including data quality, local cost, and intrinsic value affect the values of {𝑷SE,𝒒SE}superscript𝑷SEsuperscript𝒒SE\{\boldsymbol{P}^{\text{SE}},\boldsymbol{q}^{\text{SE}}\} at SE. For simplicity, we consider those clients whose equilibrium choices are in the (strict) interior of domains, i.e., 0<qnSE<qn,max0superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛SEsubscript𝑞𝑛max0<q_{n}^{\text{SE}}<q_{n,\text{max}}.

Theorem 2.

(Impact of clients’ parameters on 𝐪SEsuperscript𝐪SE\boldsymbol{q}^{\text{SE}}) For any clients i𝑖i and j𝑗j whose equilibrium qiSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖SEq_{i}^{\text{SE}} and qjSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗SEq_{j}^{\text{SE}} are in the interior of the domains, we must have ci​qi∗3ai2​Gi2+vi=cj​qj∗3aj2​Gj2+vjsubscript𝑐𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖3superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖2subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗3superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑗2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑗2subscript𝑣𝑗\frac{c_{i}{q_{i}^{*}}^{3}}{a_{i}^{2}G_{i}^{2}}+v_{i}=\frac{c_{j}{q_{j}^{*}}^{3}}{a_{j}^{2}G_{j}^{2}}+v_{j}.

Proof.

We give the proof in Appendix C. ∎

We summarize the key insights of Theorem 2 as follows:

  • •

    (Heterogeneous Data quality) Clients with larger an​Gnsubscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝐺𝑛a_{n}G_{n} (e.g., large data size and gradient norm upper-bound) have higher participation level qnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛SEq_{n}^{\text{SE}}, given the same parameters cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} and vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} among clients.

  • •

    (Local cost) Clients with large local cost parameter cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} have lower participate level qnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛SEq_{n}^{\text{SE}}, given the same parameters an​Gnsubscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝐺𝑛a_{n}G_{n} and vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} among clients.

  • •

    (Intrinsic value) It is counter-intuitive that a client with a larger intrinsic value parameter vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} has a lower participation rate qnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛SEq_{n}^{\text{SE}}, given the same an​Gnsubscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝐺𝑛a_{n}G_{n} and cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} among clients. This is because although a higher qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n} benefits its intrinsic value if its vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} is large, the server will set a lower price Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n} (as we show in the next theorem) which yields a smaller payment Pn​qnsubscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛P_{n}q_{n}. Considering that the larger qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n} also incurs larger cost cn​qn2subscript𝑐𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛2c_{n}q_{n}^{2}, qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n} should not be large.

Theorem 3.

(Impact of clients’ parameters on 𝐏SEsuperscript𝐏SE\boldsymbol{P}^{\text{SE}}) For any client n𝑛n whose equilibrium qnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛SEq_{n}^{\text{SE}} is in the interior domain, we must have

Proof.

We give the proof in Appendix D. ∎

Before we present the insights of Theorem 3, we show how parameters cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} and an​Gnsubscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝐺𝑛a_{n}G_{n} affect PnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛SEP_{n}^{\text{SE}} with the following result.

Corollary 1.

With the same threshold vtsuperscript𝑣tv^{\text{t}} in Theorem 3, and for any clients i𝑖i and j𝑗j whose equilibrium qiSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖SEq_{i}^{\text{SE}} and qjSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗SEq_{j}^{\text{SE}} are in the interior of the domains and satisfy ci​ai​Gi>cj​aj​Gjsubscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝐺𝑗c_{i}a_{i}G_{i}>c_{j}a_{j}G_{j},

    if vi<vj<vtsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗superscript𝑣tv_{i}<v_{j}<v^{\text{t}}, then PiSE>PjSE>0superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖SEsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑗SE0P_{i}^{\text{SE}}>P_{j}^{\text{SE}}>0;

  2. 2.

    if vi>vj>vtsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗superscript𝑣tv_{i}>v_{j}>v^{\text{t}}, then PiSE<PjSE<0superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖SEsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑗SE0P_{i}^{\text{SE}}<P_{j}^{\text{SE}}<0.

We summarize the key insights of Theorem 3 and Corollary 1 as follows:

  • •

    (Intrinsic value) Our result provides a quantitative criterion, which indicates the payment direction of PnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛SEP_{n}^{\text{SE}} between the server and the clients.

  • •

    (Data quality) We have shown that, no matter which payment direction, the price PnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛SEP_{n}^{\text{SE}} is higher for clients who have large values of an​Gnsubscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝐺𝑛a_{n}G_{n}, given the same parameters cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} and vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} among clients. This result demonstrates the suboptimality of existing mechanisms with uniform pricing or data quantity-based pricing.

  • •

    (Local cost) It is counter-intuitive that clients with large cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} will have higher price PnSEsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛SEP_{n}^{\text{SE}} when parameters an​Gnsubscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝐺𝑛a_{n}G_{n} and vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} are the same as other clients. However, this result makes sense because a client with a large local cost cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} tends to join with low participation level qnsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n}, which can cause a negative impact on the server’s utility. Hence, to prevent this, the server will set a higher price.

VI Experimental Evaluation

In this section, we empirically evaluate the performance of our proposed mechanism with different datasets on our hardware-based cross-device FL prototype, as illustrated in Fig. 3. Our prototype consists of N=40𝑁40N=40 Raspberry Pis serving as clients and a laptop computer acting as the central server. All devices are interconnected via an enterprise-grade Wi-Fi router. We develop a TCP-based socket interface for the communication between the server and clients.

In the following, we first present the evaluation setup and then show the experimental results.

VI-A Experimental Setup

VI-A1 Datasets and Implementations

Following similar setups as in [16, 22], we evaluate our results on three datasets, with detailed implementations as follows:

  • •

    Setup 1: The first experiment uses the Synthetic dataset, which generates 60-dimensional random vectors as input data with a non-i.i.d. S​y​n​t​h​e​t​i​c​(1,1)𝑆𝑦𝑛𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑡𝑖𝑐11Synthetic\ (1,1) setting. We generate 22,3772237722,377 data samples and distribute them among the devices in an unbalanced power-law distribution.

  • •

    Setup 2: The second experiment uses MNIST dataset, where we randomly subsample 14,4631446314,463 data samples from MNIST and distribute them among the devices in an unbalanced (following the power-law distribution) and non-i.i.d. (i.e., each device has 111–666 classes) fashion.

  • •

    Setup 3: The third experiment uses EMNIST dataset, where we randomly subsample 35,1553515535,155 lower case character samples from the EMNIST dataset and distribute among the devices in an unbalanced (i.e., numbers of data samples at each device follows a power-law distribution) and non-i.i.d. fashion (i.e., each device has a randomly chosen number of classes, ranging from 111 to 101010).

VI-A2 Model and Parameters

For all experiments, we adopt the convex multinomial logistic regression model, with 𝒘0=𝟎subscript𝒘00\boldsymbol{w}_{0}\!=\!\boldsymbol{0} and SGD batch size 242424. We use an initial learning rate of η0=0.1subscript𝜂00.1\eta_{0}=0.1, a decay rate of 0.9960.9960.996, and a local iteration number E=100𝐸100E=100. We estimate the task-related parameters α𝛼\alpha and data quality-related parameter Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n} for each setup following a similar approach as [22]. We let qn,m​a​x=1subscript𝑞𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥1q_{n,max}=1 for all n𝑛n and training round R=1000𝑅1000R=1000 for all three setups. Table I shows the parameter settings for budget B𝐵B, mean local cost parameter c¯¯𝑐\overline{c}, and mean intrinsic value parameter v¯¯𝑣\overline{v} for each setup, with c¯¯𝑐\overline{c} and v¯¯𝑣\overline{v} following exponential distribution among clients. We note that the parameters and results are general, and the specific parameters for a scenario can often be obtained through measurement in practice.

VI-B Experimental Results

We first compare the performance of our proposed optimal pricing with other benchmark pricing schemes, and then we evaluate the impact of different system parameters on the model performance and Equilibrium solution. For all three setups, we average each experiment over 202020 independent runs.

VI-B1 Comparison with Different Pricing Schemes

We compare our proposed optimal pricing 𝑷∗superscript𝑷\boldsymbol{P}^{*} with two benchmark pricing schemes: uniform pricing 𝑷usuperscript𝑷u\boldsymbol{P}^{\text{u}} where the server sets the same price for all devices, and weighted pricing 𝑷wsuperscript𝑷w\boldsymbol{P}^{\text{w}} where clients’ prices are proportional to their datasize. Then, we run experiments for all three Setups using the corresponding optimal clients’ participation levels 𝒒∗superscript𝒒\boldsymbol{q}^{*}, 𝒒usuperscript𝒒u\boldsymbol{q}^{\text{u}}, and 𝒒wsuperscript𝒒w\boldsymbol{q}^{\text{w}}, based on the above three pricing schemes. Fig. 4 illustrates the global model performance of global loss and test accuracy for different pricing schemes for Setups 111–333 with evaluating time 1,00010001,000, 2,00020002,000, and 3,00030003,000 seconds, respectively.

Loss. As shown in Figs. 4(a), 4(c), and 4(e), our proposed optimal pricing scheme achieves lower global loss with smaller variance throughout the evaluating process compared to the other benchmarks under the same budget. Specifically, for EMNIST dataset, Fig. 4(c) shows that our scheme reaches a target loss of 0.330.330.33 using around 33.1%percent33.133.1\% less time than weighted pricing and around 52.9%percent52.952.9\% less time than the uniform pricing. We summarize the superior performances of loss in Table II.

Accuracy. Figs. 4(b), 4(d), and 4(f) show that our proposed optimal pricing scheme achieves higher test accuracy with smaller variance compared to the other benchmarks under the same budget. In particular, for MNIST dataset, Fig. 4(d) shows that our proposed pricing scheme spends around 20.0%percent20.020.0\% less time than the weighted pricing and around 46.5%percent46.546.5\% less time than the uniform pricing for reaching a target accuracy of 69%percent6969\%. We summarize the superior performances of accuracy in Table III.

Clients’ Utility. Table IV shows the gain of clients’ total utility of our proposed pricing over the other two benchmarks. We see that our proposed optimal pricing scheme yields higher total clients’ utility compared to the other two benchmark pricing schemes.

The above observations validate that our designed mechanism with optimal pricing can incentivize high-quality clients to participate with higher participation levels under the same budget, which benefits both the server and clients’ utilities.

VI-B2 Impact of System Parameters

Fig. 5 - Fig. 7 show the impact of system parameters on the global model performance of our proposed mechanism with evaluating time 600600600 seconds. Due to page limit, we evaluate each parameter with one setup.

Impact of v¯¯𝑣\overline{v}: Fig. 5 shows that as clients’ mean intrinsic value v¯¯𝑣\overline{v} increases in Setup 111, the obtained model achieves a lower loss and a higher accuracy, respectively. This observation is because when clients have more interest in the global model, they have internal motivation to participate in higher levels. In addition, as predicted by our theory, we show in Table V that as v¯¯𝑣\overline{v} increases, the number of clients whose payment is negative also increases, e.g., from 00 to 555.

Impact of c¯¯𝑐\overline{c}: Fig. 6 shows that as clients’ mean local cost c¯¯𝑐\overline{c} decreases in Setup 222, the obtained model achieves a lower loss, a higher accuracy, and a smaller variance. This is because large cost prevents clients from participating in higher levels.

Impact of B𝐵B: Fig. 7 shows that as budget B𝐵B increases in Setup 333, the obtained model achieves a lower loss, a higher accuracy, and a smaller variance. This observation is because more budget allows more clients to participate in higher levels.

VII Conclusion and Future Work

In this work, we proposed a randomized client participation mechanism for FL, which guarantees that the obtained model is unbiased and converges to the globally optimal model. We derived a new tractable convergence bound that analytically characterizes the impact of clients’ participation levels and their non-i.i.d data on the server’s model performance, which yields a more accurate and customized pricing scheme. To characterize clients’ internal interests in the global model, we introduced and modeled a new intrinsic value in clients’ utilities, which allows clients to pay for the server. We showed both theoretical and empirical evidence that the intrinsic value plays a critical role in the server and clients’ decision-making. We conducted extensive experiments on a developed hardware prototype to demonstrate the superiority of our mechanism.

Our mechanism serves as an initial step towards the incentive mechanism design to achieve an unbiased and convergence guaranteed model with practical randomized client participation. In the future, we will extend our incentive mechanism for incomplete information scenarios using Bayesian method. We will further refine our cost model by decoupling the local cost into computation and communication consumption, and design an effective measurement to model clients’ intrinsic value.

Following a similar proof of convergence under full client participation [16, 32], we first show the convergence result under full client participation is 𝔼[F(𝒘¯R))]−F∗≤β/R\mathbb{E}[F\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{w}}^{R})\right)]\!-\!F^{*}\leq{\beta}/{R}, where 𝔼[F(𝒘¯R))]\mathbb{E}[F\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{w}}^{R})\right)] is the expected global loss after R𝑅R rounds with full participation, and β𝛽\beta is the same as in (11). Then, we use mathematical induction to obtain a non-recursive bound on 𝔼𝒮​(𝒒)r​‖𝒘R−𝒘∗‖2subscript𝔼𝒮superscript𝒒𝑟superscriptnormsuperscript𝒘𝑅superscript𝒘2\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{S}(\boldsymbol{q})^{r}}\left\|\boldsymbol{w}^{R}-{\boldsymbol{w}}^{*}\right\|^{2}, and show that its difference compared to the bound of full participation 𝔼​‖𝒘¯R−𝒘∗‖2𝔼superscriptnormsuperscript¯𝒘𝑅superscript𝒘2\mathbb{E}\left\|\overline{\boldsymbol{w}}^{R}-{\boldsymbol{w}}^{*}\right\|^{2} is the variance introduced in (10). After that, we converted the bound of 𝔼𝒮​(𝒒)r​‖𝒘R−𝒘∗‖2subscript𝔼𝒮superscript𝒒𝑟superscriptnormsuperscript𝒘𝑅superscript𝒘2\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{S}(\boldsymbol{q})^{r}}\left\|\boldsymbol{w}^{R}-{\boldsymbol{w}}^{*}\right\|^{2} to 𝔼​[F​(𝒘R​(𝒒))]−F∗𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘𝑅𝒒superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{R}(\boldsymbol{q})\right)]-F^{*} using L𝐿L-smoothness and strong convexity of F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot), which yields the additional term of α​∑n=1N(1−qn)​an2​Gn2qn𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁1subscript𝑞𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛2subscript𝑞𝑛\alpha{\sum\nolimits_{n=1}^{N}\frac{\left(1-q_{n}\right)a_{n}^{2}G_{n}^{2}}{q_{n}}} in (11) compared to the upper bound with full client participation. □□\hfill\square

-C Proof of Theorem 2

We write the Lagrangian function L​(𝒒,λ,μn,γn)𝐿𝒒𝜆subscript𝜇𝑛subscript𝛾𝑛L(\boldsymbol{q},\lambda,{\mu_{n}},{\gamma_{n}}) of P1′ as

-D Proof of Theorem 3

We exploit the relationship between qn∗superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛q_{n}^{*} and Pn∗superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n}^{*} in (17), and substitute it into the first order condition (22), which leads to (18). By letting Pn∗=0superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛0P_{n}^{*}=0, we have vn=1/(3​λ∗)subscript𝑣𝑛13superscript𝜆v_{n}={1}/{(3\lambda^{*})}. Therefore, given that Pn∗superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n}^{*} in (18) decreases in vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n}, we must have Pn∗>0superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛0P_{n}^{*}>0 when vn<1/(3​λ∗)subscript𝑣𝑛13superscript𝜆v_{n}<{1}/{(3\lambda^{*})}, and Pn∗<0superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑛0P_{n}^{*}<0 when vn>1/(3​λ∗)subscript𝑣𝑛13superscript𝜆v_{n}>{1}/{(3\lambda^{*})}. Hence, we conclude the proof by letting the threshold vt=1/(3​λ∗)superscript𝑣t13superscript𝜆v^{\text{t}}={1}/{(3\lambda^{*})}. ∎
